title: Clippers' 2019 playoff loss to Warriors 'helped' Kawhi Leonard make decision
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Trysta Krick and Mark Medina break down the Los Angeles Clippers who all of a sudden find themselves at the top of the crop with the additions of Kawhi Leonard and Paul George . USA TODAY

SAN FRANCISCO – The Los Angeles Clippers did not need to entice Kawhi Leonard with fancy dinners or glitzy tribute videos. Even before he met the Clippers this summer, Leonard already was sold on the franchise’s direction.

He only needed to watch how the Clippers challenged the Golden State Warriors last season in the first round of the NBA playoffs.

“They played with a lot of confidence and they knew they could play,” Leonard said of the six-game series. “They wanted to guard everybody on the team at that point. That helped out (my decision).”

So, Leonard joined the Clippers after winning his second NBA championship and Finals MVP, with Toronto, at the Warriors’ expense.

In the Clippers’ 141-122 win over the Warriors on Thursday at Chase Center, Leonard and his teammates validated his vision on how a partnership with Paul George, acquired from Oklahoma City and sitting out while he recovers from offseason shoulder surgery, would work.

Kawhi Leonard looks at the scoreboard during the first half of the the Clippers' rout of the Warriors in San Francisco. (Photo: The Associated Press)

OPINION: Lakers-Clippers can become rivalry even if Lakers will always own LA

Leonard finished with 21 points while shooting 9-of-17 from the field. He also had nine assists and six rebounds in 21 minutes. Two days after Leonard scored 30 points on 12-of-19 shooting in the Clippers’ season-opening win over the Los Angeles Lakers, the Warriors doubled Leonard and dared him to become a playmaker. So he did.

The Clippers’ Lou Williams (22 points), Patrick Patterson (20), Montrezl Harrell (18), Ivica Zubac (16 points, 10 rebounds), and Landry Shamet (11 points) also cracked double figures. As Clippers coach Doc Rivers said, “that shows the trust he has in his teammates.”

And why wouldn’t Leonard trust his teammates? After observing the Clippers last season, Leonard said he “pretty much knew their character.” Leonard’s teammates displayed the same mindset that enabled them to challenge the top-seeded Warriors in the first round of the NBA playoffs only six months ago.

“The fight we showed in that series absolutely helped in recruiting Paul and Kawhi,” Rivers said. “They saw the grit of the team and seriousness of it. What player wouldn’t want to join that?”

Said guard Patrick Beverley: “It comes with the character of the team. Of course, Doc is a psycho genius with all of his plays. But that’s the dynamic of our team.”

Meanwhile, the Warriors were forced to rebuild after Kevin Durant left among several moves. They still have Stephen Curry and Draymond Green, but they have nine new players.

“The Clippers have built something. What I admire about them is that it’s not just that they had a good summer. It’s what they did before that,” Warriors coach Steve Kerr said. “They really built a foundation where they defended with energy. They had some grit to them and fought for everything.”

The Clippers’ foundation seemed sturdy in only their second game of the regular season. They held the Warriors to 39.5% shooting. They outscored them 46-33 in the third quarter. They led by as many as 31.

The Warriors experienced serious adjustments beyond hosting their first regular-season game at Chase Center after playing full-time at Oracle Arena in Oakland since 1971. The crowd sounded just as loud. The Warriors’ ability to become a lovable and scrappy underdog only went so far. While Green played only 28 minutes because of a right elbow contusion that he described as “pretty dead and painful,” Kevon Looney lasted only 10 minutes before leaving with right hamstring tightness.

It does not seem to be a coincidence that Leonard ruined the Warriors’ final game at Oracle Arena and their first game at Chase Center.

“I feel like those guys have their chemistry already,” Leonard said. “Once PG and I came with the young fellas, they wanted us to do our thing. They welcomed us in with open arms and wanted us to be ourselves.”

Kawhi Leonard and Paul George smile while sitting on the bench during their game against the Golden State Warriors. (Photo: Ezra Shaw, Getty Images)

To become themselves, the Clippers held a player-only training camp in early September that entailed plenty of scrimmages. They preached the importance of having consistent ball movement. They held frequent team dinners. They even hosted an early Halloween party.

“I think that carries over to the court,” Leonard said. “You feel comfortable talking to a guy when he makes a mistake.”

For example, Zubac drew whistles often after Leonard set him up. Zubac apologized: “They keep fouling me; I can’t get you assists.”

Leonard answered: “As long as you score free throws and we get a win, I don’t care about stats.”

Follow USA TODAY NBA writer Mark Medina on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram.
description: L.A. Clippers star Kawhi Leonard became impressed with how the Clippers challenged the Golden State Warriors in last season's playoffs.
